prompt: Which equivalence rule shows that (P → Q) ≡ (¬P ∨ Q)?
hint: This rule defines implication in terms of disjunction and negation.
explanation: Material Implication: (P → Q) is logically equivalent to (¬P ∨ Q). 'If P then Q' means the same as 'Either not-P or Q'. Both are false only when P is true and Q is false.
visual_concept: Two ways to say the same thing: 'If it rains, I'll bring an umbrella' = 'Either it won't rain, or I'll bring an umbrella'.
